Women in Tech 2018 & 2019

I designed the branding for a conference focused on the empowerment of women and non-binary people in the tech industry, with input from a team of talented peers.

2018 and 2019 logos for Women in Tech (Click for full view)

  • time range: July-August 2018, June-September 2019
  • client: Tufts Women in Computer Science
  • tools: Sketch, Adobe Illustrator
  • team members: Kate Hanson, Anita Lam, Lexi Walker (2018); Eva Denman, Kate Hanson, Jen Han, Malia Kiang, Lily Zhang (2019)

The first time I tried to design this logo, I felt rather restricted in coming up with appropriate symbolism for the conference and its mission. I had a case of designer's block where my only ideas involved the stereotypical "female" symbol, which I didn't want since we really wanted to celebrate women and nonbinary people. I went back to the drawing board with the intent of doing more research.

I then had some very open discussions with the organizers and the head of marketing for the 2018 conference. How do we position this event as an invitation for inclusive, feminist action? How does branding play a role in having people of marginalized identity to participate and not just white, cisgendered women? What limitations need to be acknowledged now, so that they can inform the marketing? These complex questions could not be answered immediately, but I found them important as I considered the visual vocabulary for the branding.

First false start at designing the logo
2018 sketches, following the idea of a lightbulb/circuitry design

With the organizers' blessing, a lot of thinking, and Pinterest boards, I made some sketches with a more gender-neutral appearance, using the imagery of a lightbulb and circuitry, and sometimes incorporating a "W" or coding braces. These elements center the themes of person-to-person connection that we hoped to foster at the conference.

Alternate, less simplified logo

For the 2018 conference I had come up with a simple lightbulb logo highlighted by an offset, yellow background color that pulled it all together and also informed the rest of the branding. I chose purple, teal, and yellow as a nod to the bold-colored branding of other tech events. The palette also has a history of being less traditionally feminine. The downside to this palette was the eye-strain and lack of contrast that made the design less appealing in retrospect.

Still, the 2018 conference was successful and I was lucky to join the marketing team again in 2019 and reimagine my work from before. With feedback from my teammates, I experimented with many color palettes and settled on an expanded but cohesive suite of options that are hopefully easier on the eyes. From there I took the time to make a wide variety of graphics and branding materials that others could use as jumping-off points.

WiT 2018 poster (click to view)
Ads in print, Eventbrite, and Instagram formats for WiT 2019 (Click for full view)

Since joining the marketing team for Women in Tech in 2018, the conference has been one of my favorite experiences. It's incredibly rewarding to have played such a huge part in boosting the visibility of an event like this, which I've also been able to enjoy as an attendee.
